title: Protocol for single-cell ATAC sequencing using combinatorial indexing in mouse lung adenocarcinoma
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
This protocol includes a number of adaptions and optimization from prior methodologies (Chen et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2], Cusanovich et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3], Lake et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7], Pliner et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10], Preissl et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]).
Sample preparation
Preparation of samples will depend on sample collection methodology (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2], Day 1 overview). For cell lines, we recommend detachment of cells with trypsin or accutase and then proceed to fixation and transposition. Fresh cells should be isolated or viably frozen cells should be thawed immediately and washed 1–2 times with 1× PBS before the start of the protocol. This protocol describes the specific steps for using fresh murine lung tumor samples (LaFave et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). Lung tumors are isolated from KrasG12D/+; Trp53-/-; Rosa26tom/+ mice and dissociated cells are sorted for tdTomato expression to isolate tumor cells for sciATAC-seq. Tumors are induced at 6–8 weeks of age and late stage tumors are collected at 25 weeks post-tumor induction (LaFave et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). Cell preparations can be used fresh or viably frozen in media (DMEM + 10% FCS) and 10% DMSO; however, we recommend performing the sort of the day of the experiment on viably frozen tumor cells.

Figure 2. Overview of Day 1 of the protocol before an overnight stopping point
Day 1 of the protocol includes sample preparation and fixation, transposition in a 96 well plate, sample pooling, re-splitting the samples and reverse crosslinking. Reverse crosslinking occurs overnight and the protocol is resumed at Day 2. Created with biorender.com[href=http://biorender.com].
Timing: [Day 1]
Collection of lung adenocarcinoma cells
Timing: [4 hrs]
Euthanize mouse using an isoflurane chamber.
Dissect whole tumor-burdened lung or individual tumors and place in 1.5 mL Eppendorf microcentrifuge tubes containing 100 μL Lung Digestion Buffer. Buffer is based on manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/lung-dissociation-kit-mouse.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/lung-dissociation-kit-mouse.html#gref]).

Thinly mince tissues using scissors and then add an additional 0.5 mL Lung Digestion Buffer to tube.
Incubate at 37°C with rotation for 30 min.
Grind sample over a 100 μM filter into a 50 mL conical tube with pipette tip.
Pipette 5 mL S-MEM over the filter to wash remaining sample into the tube.
Pellet cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min. Note: Centrifugation speed and time may be adjusted according to sample type.
Remove supernatant and resuspend pellet in 1 mL ACK lysis buffer to lyse red blood cells. Incubate on the bench at 25°C for 2 min.
Quench reaction by adding 10 mL DMEM and pellet by centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min.
Resuspend pellet in 500 μL of FACS Buffer. Stain samples with APC-conjugated CD45 (BD, 559864), CD11b (eBioscience, 15-0112-82), CD31 (BioLegend, 102510), and Ter119 (BD, 557909) at a concentration of 1:1000, and DAPI (stock concentration 5 mg/mL; stain at a concentration of 1:10000).
Note: Use of a dead cell removal kit (e.g., Miltenyi cat no. 103-090-101) is recommended.
Sort for APCneg (immune depleted), tdTomatopos, and DAPIneg into FACS buffer using a FACS Aria (example gating scheme, Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Proceed to fixation and transposition.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/691-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Gating strategy for lung adenocarcinoma cells
FACS-depletion strategy is shown (TER119-APC, CD31-APC, CD11b-APC, and CD19-APC) and DAPI for a live-dead stain. tdTom+ positive populations (APC negative, DAPI positive) are collected for fixation and transposition. Figure reprinted with permission from LaFave et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6].
Fixation and transposition
Permeabilized cells are prepared and uniquely barcoded Tn5 transposases label open regions of chromatin.
Timing: [Day 1]
Assemble Tn5
Timing: [45 min]
Prepare Dilution Buffer, then cool on ice for 5 min. The dilution buffer can be stored at −20°C for several months.

Critical: Assemble Tn5 immediately before fixation and transposition steps.
Prepare 1× Tn5 by diluting homemade Tn5 in Dilution Buffer to a final volume of 96 μL.
Mix diluted Tn5 1:1 with pre-annealed adapters/glycerol mix by combining 4 μL diluted Tn5 with 4 μL each pre annealed adapter (20 adapters in total).
Note: For 96 transposition reactions, 8 sciAD1.X and 12 sciAD2.X distinct barcodes are used, see Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4] for barcode combinations.
table:files/protocols_protocol_691_14.csv
Incubate on the bench at 25°C for 30 min.
After 30 min, proceed to fixation and transposition steps but keep on ice.
Fixation
Timing: [1 hr]
Pellet cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 3 min.
Critical: Always coat tubes with 7.5% BSA before spinning to improve cell recovery. Add BSA to coat the entire tube and remove prior to cell fixation.
Critical: Always use a swing bucket rotor for centrifugation instead of a tabletop centrifuge.
Note: Centrifugation time and speed may need to be adjusted for sample type based on prior experience.
Resuspend pellets in 100 μL cold 1× PBS.
Count cells by mixing 5 μL of each sample to 5 μL of trypan blue using a hemocytometer.
Note: Visually check samples for clumping and debris which may cause issues in future steps (Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Dilute each sample to 100K cells in a final volume of 100 μL.
Note: If cell concentration cannot be achieved, resuspend the entire cell sample in 100 μL. Variations to cell number must be accounted for at the PCR barcoding step by maintaining an appropriate cell density per reaction.
Pellet cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 3 min.
Dilute 16% formaldehyde to 1.6% with H2O.
Fix cells by adding 6.7 μL 1.6% formaldehyde (final concentration 0.1%). Mix samples by pipetting (Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5]).

Note: Fixation conditions have been optimized in specific human and mouse cells lines and have been successful in several tissues including lung and brain. Fixation percentage can be tuned from 0.1%–0.5% depending on cell fragility.
Note: Omitting the fixation step may enable experiments with limited cell number, but will increase the level of crosstalk between single cells due to excess debris in the sample prep (LaFave et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
Incubate on the bench at 25°C for 5 min.
Prepare a master mix of 5.6 μL 2.5M glycine, 5.0 μL 1 M pH 8.0 Tris, and 1.3 μL 7.5% BSA for each 100 μL fixed sample. Stop the fixation by adding 11.9 uL master mix to each individual sample.
Incubate on ice for 10 min.
Gently wash the cells with 0.5 mL of 1× PBS by pipetting against the side of the tube without resuspending the pellet. Spin at 500 × g for 3 min.
Repeat step k.
Resuspend pellets in 1 μL 1× PBS for each transposition reaction as necessary for pre-determined number of reactions.
Note: Use approximately 1K cells for each transposition reaction. Adjust the number of reactions per sample depending on desired number of reactions (e.g., if performing 12 transposition reactions per sample, resuspend 12K cells in 12 μL 1× PBS). In total, samples should be split across the 96-well plate (e.g., an example experiment may be 8 samples and 12 transposition reactions per sample to complete the plate).

Note: Multiplexed barcoding allows for transposition of different samples/conditions in the same experiment. Samples should remain separated at this step for labeling by transposition. Based on what percentage of cells needed from each sample/condition, the researcher will need to determine the number of 96 wells that correspond to each sample. The researcher should keep track of the sample in each well for demultiplexing purposes.
Transposition
Timing: [1.5 h]
Prepare Transposition Buffer and Nuclei Isolation Buffer.
In a 96 well plate, combine 7 μL of the transposition buffer and 1 μL fixed cells in each well.
Incubate on the bench at 25°C for 10 min.
Dilute the assembled Tn5 1:1 by adding 8 μL Transposition Buffer to 8 μl assembled Tn5. Add 1 μL diluted Tn5 containing sciAD1.X oligo and 1 μL diluted Tn5 containing sciAD2.X oligo to each well based on plate map (Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4]).
Shake at 300 rpm for 30 min at 37°C using the Eppendorf ThermoMixer C.
Quench the reaction by adding 1 μL of 0.5M EDTA to each well. Mix well by pipetting.
Shake at 300 rpm for 15 min at 37°C.
Combine transposition reactions and prepare for PCR barcoding
Transposed samples are pooled together and re-aliquoted into individual wells to add another level of barcoding at PCR amplification.
Pool transposition reactions
Timing: [30 min]
Pool all reactions from each well of the 96 well plate (approximately 1 mL in total) into a BSA-coated 1.5 mL Eppendorf microcentrifuge tube. Add 38.4 μL 1M MgCl2 to quench EDTA and mix by pipetting.
Pellet cells by centrifugation at 500 × g for 2 min.
Remove supernatant and wash cells with 1 mL Nuclei Isolation Buffer before centrifugation at 500 × g for 2 min.

Resuspend pellet with 0.5 mL Nuclei Isolation Buffer and pass the entire volume through a 40 μm Flowmi cell strainer for 1000 μL pipette tips into a new Eppendorf tube.
Count cells using a hemocytometer and dilute transposed cells to a concentration of 13.3 cells/μL in Nuclei Isolation Buffer.
Note: Final volume is dependent on the number of 96 well plates used for PCR amplification.
Reverse crosslinking
Timing: [18 h]
Prepare 2× Reverse Crosslinking Buffer (RCB).
Add 2 μL of 20 mg/mL proteinase K per 1 mL of RCB.
Note: 1 mL of RCB is required for each PCR plate. To increase recovery of cells, the protocol can be scaled up to 9 individual 96 well PCR plates.
Create master mixes for each sciP1.x primer and each sciP2.x primer to aliquot in a 96 well plate.
Note: An example of how to aliquot primers across the plate can be found in Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5].
table:files/protocols_protocol_691_15.csv
Prepare Master Mix 1 with the transposed cell sample (concentration 13.3 cells/μL determined above) and 10 μM sciP1.X for each row. To do this, add 15 μL of the transposed cells to 5 μL of each primer sciP1.X (12 total).
Prepare Master Mix 2 with 10 μM sciP2.X and RCB with proteinase K for each column. To do this, add 50 μL RCB + proteinase K to 10 μL each primer sciP2.X (8 total).
Note: Prepare Master Mix 1 and Master Mix 2 in PCR tubes to allow for multichannel pipetting when distributing across the 96 well plate.
Distribute 2 μL of Master Mix 1 across the 96-well plate according to the example in Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5].
Distribute 3 μL of Master Mix 2 across the 96-well plate according to the example in Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5].

Note: Each well should have 2.5 μL RCB with proteinase K, 0.5 μL 10 μM sciP1.X, 0.5 μL 10 μM sciP2.X, and 1.5 μL transposed cells. Master Mix 2 is made in excess and leftover is expected.
Note: In the nomenclature for PCR barcodes, sciP1.X and sciP2.X, X refers to the full repertoire of barcoding space.
Incubate in a thermal cycler at 55°C for 1 h to 16 h.
Pause Point: Shorter incubation times from 1–16 h can be used. We recommend 16 h to provide a convenient stopping point between Day 1 and Day 2 of the protocol.
PCR amplification and quantification
Addition of barcodes through PCR and quality check prior to sequencing (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4], Day 2 overview).

Figure 4. Overview of Day 2 of the protocol and downstream analysis
Day 2 of the protocol requires PCR of split samples, qPCR to identify the number of additional PCR cycles required for minimal library amplification, pooling of libraries and library quantification. The libraries can then be sequenced and analyzed for downstream applications. Created with biorender.com[href=http://biorender.com]
Timing: [Day 2]
PCR Amplification
Timing: [45 min]
Remove PCR plate from thermal cycler and briefly spin down plate at 300 × g for 10 seconds.
Quench reaction by adding 5 μL 10% Tween20 to each well. Mix well by pipetting using a multichannel pipette.
Prepare PCR master mix by combining 1.25 mL 2× NEBNext PCR mix and 250 μL nuclease free H2O.
Add 15 μL of the PCR mix solution to each well using a multichannel pipette. Pipette to mix and spin down plate.

Quantitative PCR
Timing: [2 h]
After the initial 5 cycles of amplification, remove the plate from the thermal cycler and keep on ice for the duration of this step.

For a quality check, randomly choose 4–8 wells to use for quantitative PCR (qPCR) reactions to determine the number of additional cycles needed for the entire plate. A negative control using water instead of DNA is advised.
Prepare qPCR master mix. Scale up based on the number of wells chosen to test above.
Add 9 μL qPCR master each well of qPCR plate. Add 1 μL sample to each well.
Perform qPCR reaction to saturation as follows:
table:files/protocols_protocol_691_17.csv
Determine the number of additional PCR cycles. To do this, the fluorescence signal is normalized to the range of 0–1. The ⅓ CT is calculated as the qPCR cycle number to reach 0.33. The additional PCR cycle number is calculated by subtracting 5 from ⅓ CT value calculated by qPCR (Additional cycle N = ⅓ CT - 5) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).

Run qPCR reactions on a Lonza FlashGelTM DNA cassette 2.2% gel for 9 min at 250 Volts.
After running, the gel is imaged in a Biorad Gel Doc XR or similar UV trans-illuminator.
Note: Confirm that you see the expected fragmentation pattern following ATAC-seq (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]). Failed experiment will appear as primer dimers and means that the experiment was not successful (Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5]).

Figure 6. Expected fragmentation patterns from sciATAC-seq protocol
qPCR products run on a FlashGel dock to confirm appropriate ATAC-seq library prep. Samples show fragmentation patterns. Negative control shows only a primer dimer and the absence of fragmented DNA. A failed prep would appear as a primer dimer without fragmented DNA.

Quantification of minimally amplified libraries
Timing: [2 h]
Pool all the post-PCR samples into a 15 mL conical tube.
Note: Pool samples from each plate into separate conical tubes.
Purify DNA using Qiagen MinElute PCR purification column following manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=c1276626-d0b2-4e95-b2c3-dc81803a198c&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=c1276626-d0b2-4e95-b2c3-dc81803a198c&lang=en]). Elute in 12 μL EB buffer.
Pause Point: Purified libraries can be stored at −20°C until quantification via qPCR.
Dilute 1 μL sample 100,000× in KAPA dilution buffer. This can be accomplished by serially diluting the sample 100×, then 100×, then 10× for quantification of purified libraries using the KAPA quantification kit.
Prepare qPCR reactions by adding 6 μL KAPA SYBR FAST qPCR Master Mix with added Primer Premix and 4 μL diluted sample or provided standards (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]) to each well. Perform quantification reactions in triplicate.

Next-generation sequencing and data processing
Libraries can be sequenced on the Next-seq platform (Illumina) using a 150-cycle kit without custom sequencing primer based on the below barcoding strategy (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]). The following read lengths must be used: Read 1: 47 cycles, Index 1: 36 cycles, Index 2: 36 cycles, Read 2: 47 cycles.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/691-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Overview of barcoding strategy
The barcoding strategy has been updated to avoid sequencing with custom primers. sciAD1.X, sciAD2.X, sciP1.X, and sciP2.X ultimately assign four unique barcodes (bc1-4) per cell. Read 1 (R1) and Read 2 (R2) are flanked by the Tn5 mosaic end (ME) transposition recognition sequences.
Note: We suggest to sequence 20–40K reads per cell, but the number of required reads may vary depending on the sample quality.
Convert base calls to fastq format using bcl2fastq.

Trim sequencing reads to remove adapter sequences using trim_galore <filename(s)>. trim_galore automatically detects Nextera adapter sequences and trims low quality reads.
Align reads to hg19 or mm10 genome using Bowtie2 (Langmead and Salzberg, 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]) using maximum fragment length set to 2 kb and all other default settings (bowtie2 -X2000 --rg-id).
Demultiplex tolerating one mismatch base within barcodes.
Remove mitochondrial and low-quality reads using SAMtools (Li et al., 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16]) (samtools view -b -q 30 -f 0x2).
Remove duplicate sequences with picard toolkit (http://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/[href=http://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/])
Call peaks from a single alignment (.bam) file using input peak calling with MACS v2.1.2 (MACS2). Use default options with the following flags set: -nomodel, -nolambda, -keep-dup all, -call-summits returning a list of single base pair peak summits with FDR q < 0.01.
Note: If calling peaks across multiple experiments, aggregate each sample into one .bam file. Call peaks on each sample to obtain sample-specific peaks.
Identify a list of significant, non-overlapping fixed width peak windows by padding peak summits with 150 base pairs at either side to generate 301 base pair window peak regions.
Sort peaks in decreasing order of significance scores. Remove peak windows with the lower significance scores and keep the most significant peak. Repeat over an iterative process, to identify 301 base pair disjoin peak windows.
Using the generated peak list above, determine the number of reads overlapping a given peak window for each unique cell barcode.
Generate a peak X cell counts matrix which corresponds to ATAC reads in peaks for each cell profiled.
